comments.body: retest this please

Changes looks ok to me. Just curious, are we handling mtu change? I think if mtu value is changed by user for a port, we set this to kernel. Are we also updating the corresponding SAI router interface mtu?

Thanks Prince for the review.
No. We are unable to handling the if mtu changes for a router interfaces. We need SAI support, current the attribute can only be passed down to ASIC during the router interface creation. There is no exsiting SAI API available to update the attribute of a router interfaces.

Thanks,Haiyang------------------------------------------------------------------From:Prince Sunny <notifications@github.com>Time:2017 Nov 30 (Thu) 17:08To:Azure/sonic-swss <sonic-swss@noreply.github.com>Cc:Haiyang <haiyang.z@alibaba-inc.com>; Author <author@noreply.github.com>Subject:Re: [Azure/sonic-swss] Ip mtu settings (#402)
Changes looks ok to me. Just curious, are we handling mtu change? I think if mtu value is changed by user for a port, we set this to kernel. Are we also updating the corresponding SAI router interface mtu?

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
retest this please

the PR name is IP MTU, but the ConfigDB schema is PORT MTU.

Since it is IP MTU, I think we should add in the INTERFACE:xxx: object. 

Check below
``` 
127.0.0.1:6379[4]> keys VLAN_INTER*
1) "VLAN_INTERFACE|Vlan2|172.0.0.1/26"
127.0.0.1:6379[4]> hgetall "VLAN_INTERFACE|Vlan2|172.0.0.1/26"
1) "mtu"
2) "9000"
```

Also do you have the code to listen to configdb?

@JipanYanga  to review.

I think we should modify the intfmgrd to listen to configdb, meanwhile write to APPDB directly. We should not listen to netlink message any more.

@lguohan 

Thanks for the code review. 

As we discussed earlier, there should be only one source of the MTU settings in config DB  for linux kernel host interface, port/LAG, and router interface created on the port/LAG. So with my previous merged pull request (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/402/commits/51158b3e7b68b37f454bbeccee3d2242d8d9aaa7), only port syncd listens to CONFIG DB, and update the port MTU and Kernel MTU. Then when a router interfaces is created on the port, it get the MTU from netlink, and pass it down to router_interface_create.

For vlan/vlan interfaces MTU settings, let me discuss with Jipan offline first and then update with you.

BTW, how to restart the test? The other pull request has been merged, and the build should be fixed now.

Thanks,
Haiyang

@hzheng5 , even though SAI does not support router interface MTU set, our orchagent code should still support that MTU change in my opinion, then later we can close it by adding SAI support for this MTU change which I think should not be difficult.
@prsunny , I do not see router interface mtu support in broadcom sai, can you confirm? It looks like this PR will break the broadcom platform if we check in.

in this PR, you introduced a new field (if_mtu) in INTERFACE object, which is not necessary. We already have an MTU field in the PORT_TABLE. I think we can use that. 

in the intforch.cpp, when it tries to create router interface, it should check the port_mtu, and setup the router interface mtu accordingly. then the mtu changes, the portsorch will get the mtu notification change, and if it is a router interface, it should also change the router interface mtu. Then, we do not need to change intfsyncd.cpp at all.
also, can you add swss integration tests in the next iteration for the mtu changes. Examples are https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/tree/master/tests
retest this please
@hzheng5 , to restart the test, just add a comment "retest this please"
@lguohan, @hzheng5, from what I've observed, there is NO Broadcom support for SAI_ROUTER_INTERFACE_ATTR_MTU in the current code. This check-in will break the Broadcom platforms.
Thanks @prsunny  any idea when SAI_ROUTER_INTERFACE_ATTR_MTU will be added to the brcm libsai? Will it be available before Dec 15 release?
retest this please

@lguohan  Thanks for your code review.  I have updated the diff and tried to answer your comments. Please see inline.

For your last comment:
"in this PR, you introduced a new field (if_mtu) in INTERFACE object, which is not necessary. We already have an MTU field in the PORT_TABLE. I think we can use that.

in the intforch.cpp, when it tries to create router interface, it should check the port_mtu, and setup the router interface mtu accordingly. then the mtu changes, the portsorch will get the mtu notification change, and if it is a router interface, it should also change the router interface mtu. Then, we do not need to change intfsyncd.cpp at all."

I'm adding the changes in intfsyncd because I want to follow the complete config path as other router interfaces attributes as from intfsyncd->app_db->intfsorch->asic_db. And the if_mtu is already defined in swss schema for router interfaces.  If we bypass intfsyncd, app_db won't have the if_mtu value for  router_interfaces, and it's not consistent with other router interfaces attributes.

Sure. I will add some swss intergration test shortly.

Thanks,
Haiyang
@hzheng5 Hello Haiyang. Yes. The SAI_ROUTER_INTERFACE_ATTR_MTU attribute is not supported right now and will be available AFTER Dec 15 when the SAI header version moves to 1.2.

OK. I see. Thanks Shuotian for the update.------------------------------------------------------------------From:Shuotian Cheng <notifications@github.com>Time:2017 Dec 7 (Thu) 22:41To:Azure/sonic-swss <sonic-swss@noreply.github.com>Cc:Haiyang <haiyang.z@alibaba-inc.com>; Mention <mention@noreply.github.com>Subject:Re: [Azure/sonic-swss] Ip mtu settings (#402)
@hzheng5 Hello Haiyang. Yes. The SAI_ROUTER_INTERFACE_ATTR_MTU attribute is not supported right now and will be available AFTER Dec 15 when the SAI header version moves to 1.2.

@hzheng5 , it is not neccessary to have two mtu attribute for the same physical interface, one for the port mtu and one for the router interface. If you look at the other router configuration (like cisco), you won't see it. 

Is there any flaw in the workflow I suggested? it will be simpler for people to understand. since there is only one mtu for the port. If the port becomes a port-based router interface, the same mtu value will be applied to the router interface mtu.

@lguohan Sure. The workflow you suggested sounds good to me. Will remove the intfsyncd and app_DB changes. 
Thanks, Haiyang

in this PR, you introduced a new field (if_mtu) in INTERFACE object, which is not necessary. We already have an MTU field in the PORT_TABLE. I think we can use that.

in the intforch.cpp, when it tries to create router interface, it should check the port_mtu, and setup the router interface mtu accordingly. then the mtu changes, the portsorch will get the mtu notification change, and if it is a router interface, it should also change the router interface mtu. Then, we do not need to change intfsyncd.cpp at all.

Sorry the PR description is not clear to me. What are you blaming? Where is the bug? How do you fix it?
Checking the code, do you actually mean gPortsOrch->getPort() is not working as expected? If yes could you just fix that function? #Closed

I think getPort() is returning a copy of port object. I think that API may or may not by design. That is why the fix is not fix getPort(), instead it is using getAllPorts() to get the real port object to prevent the resource leak.
@oleksandrivantsiv , do you have a step to reproduce the problem? once we get your step, we can later add a swss test on the virtual switch to test it.

@lguohan I agree there may be a bug in getPort. If this is the case, @oleksandrivantsiv could you add a // TODO comment to the code snippet for 'getPort', and we will revert this change after fixing the real bug.

To reproduce the issue it is enough to create two or more ACL tables. Only one table will be bind to ports. Other won't work.

getPort function was implemented to work with stateless port object. The issue was introduced when AclOrch was refactored and port object became stateful in https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/commit/0c98cc36b420fd33fc8066b1f140f6515bb00a76 commit. getPort wasn't adopted to that changes.

comments.body: This change is required for PFC WD. It will allow a quick lookup with queue OID as a key.
it is a temp workaround
will plan accordingly.

The flexport feature is defined here, https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/wiki/Port-Breakout-and-Speed 

The design is also available here. https://github.com/Azure/SONiC/wiki/Port-Breakout-High-Level-Design

Please take a look at the feature and let us know your concern.

To your first question, create_port/remove_port is a basic SAI API. It should be supported by every SAI library. Once vendor SAI supports this feature in a couple of month we can remove the check.

A general question, is there mechanism at SAI layer to check whether an API and an attribute is supported at running time?   if not it might be good to add that support so we don't need to add platform dependent check in PI code in the future.

As a temp workaround,  I'm ok with the change to quickly get around the syncd crash problem.
yes, sai can check the api, but swss is calling sairedis. we need feedback from sairedis, which needs more time to do it.

I do not understand your point that this commit id does not solve the crash issue. it does solve the crash issue. 

I agree this is not the ideal way of doing it as I mentioned in my reply and the code comment, this is a temp workaround until we find time to do it in a right way.

As for plan for the right fix, I think we can discuss with PM on the timeline and priority. This FlexPort feature does solve the problem that you do not need to have multiple sai profile for the same platform in case of port breakout. I do not see why we need to revert the original PR.

The crash happened in syncd when calling the API function with null pointer.  We should either force all the SAI library to have valid pointers for all functions (including stub functions in case no implementation of the real functions.), or we have to check the API function pointers validness before calling it. 
PD code in PI functions is not ideal, maybe we can address this by having a valid API map at swss level by query ASIC SAI lib during the init, then we decide whether we should call the API or not.

Also, fundamentally, we do need address the case where we got failure from SAI lib call as well ( resource failure etc...)

@zhenggen-xu , the SAI api in swss level is the sairedis function pointer.  currently swss does not have a way to get the actually SAI API function pointer. 

@nikos-li, let's focus on this specific issue first. Let's plan to the longer term fix. The feature is useful, and it does not cause crash on other platforms. Do we really want to block it?

@lguohan Understood the swss using sairedis function pointer.  what I meant was to have a map which will be filled in during the initialization so we know whether the ASIC SAI API is valid or not. The other problem is, even if the SAI API function pointer is valid but not implemented, syncd would not be able to feedback to swss for more action currently. 
Given that we may not be able to address this in a short time, I think we can keep this change, but at the same time, I suggest to log a few bugs:
1,  SAI API function pointer validness should be checked before calling sairedis API. This might be done by some query at init time.
2, SAI API failure feedback need to be done, we can not just crash swss if SAI API fails.
3, A bug should be logged so that we don't forget to remove the PD code in PI area later.
address issue https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/issues/235
@zhenggen-xu , issues created. https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/issues/239 and https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/issues/238
If we are ok with the workaround and the plan of next step,  could we merge the code change asap to avoid syncd segmentation fault crash under this specific scenario?  thanks!
Let me know if I can merge now?
@lguohan I am not blocking this on the assumption that the PD checks you introduced will be removed by end of year.

reviews.body: It is not acceptable nor correct to hardcode platform checks in PI code. The orchagent shouldn't care what the platform is. So is this meant to be a short term solution?

- What is the planned design for a permanent fix? Is there one?
- Who will work on the permanent fix?
- What is the timeline for it?

- Kindly share the planning with the community. It's not reasonable to have such an open ended item with no concrete planning to fix. Especially since there are other mlnx platform specific checks that have polluted the PI code and I haven't seen any efforts to address them so far.
- Who needs this feature and by when? Why shouldn't this be backed out and the proper solution implemented?

I'm sorry but this isn't the right solution.

You are not solving the crash. You are simply trying to bypass it. And in that effort, you have added more platform specific checks to PI code which is not acceptable.

Lets assume an asic vendor implements support for the SAI APIs. The code still wouldn't work unless they go through the PI code and evaluate all the PD checks in it and take appropriate action. This coupling between PI and PD is not desirable nor acceptable. Not even as an interim solution.

The correct solution is for each SAI API to have a default/stub function hooked up which the vendor's SAI implementation overrides. The return code must be one that doesn't cause a crash in any daemon.

To unblock the community, the correct approach is to backout/revert the original commit so that you have the time to work on the proper solution.

You shouldn't commit these diffs - they are a very bad hack and you are suggesting it should exist until all asic vendors implement the APIs (for which we have no control or guarantees). It also sets a very bad precedent and an example to avoid on the coupling of PI and PD code.

The proposed fix doesn't address the actual root cause. That's why I said it doesn't solve the crash but bypasses it.

It's also evident in the code that the PD checks already present, which shouldn't have existed in the first place, are not getting addressed/fixed. So allow me to have my doubts that this one will be addressed.

I already mentioned the problems from such a temporary fix and there are many more which I haven't brought up. The disadvantages far outweigh the argument that we should keep the code and not revert. The code should be kept clean - many people are now relying on it and we need to be more responsible and do the right thing.

We have debated this extensively. These changes shouldn't be committed IMO and to help out I have outlined what the right solution is in previous post.

@lguohan The intent is never to block or revert a feature that has merged. Can you commit that https://github.com/Azure/sonic-sairedis/issues/238 will be fixed by the end of the year and the platform checks/workaround you have introduced here will be removed?

comments.body: The PR has dependency on https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/327
@JipanYanga , can you rebase your code and resolve the conflict?

I did a rebase against master branch.  Before the possible merge for this PR is done, the libsai from ASIC vendors should support SAI_HOSTIF_VLAN_TAG_STRIP and SAI_HOSTIF_VLAN_TAG_KEEP 
 for attribute SAI_HOSTIF_ATTR_VLAN_TAG  in both sai_create_hostif_fn() and sai_set_hostif_attribute_fn().   

The broadcom libsai I tested has support for them from 3.0.3.3.  Current version of broadcom libsai in sonic-buildimage repo is 3.0.3.2-6 .  https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/platform/broadcom/sai.mk

@JipanYanga , 3.0.3.2-6 does not support STRIP/KEEP attribute value, it will cause the T0 to break. For normal VLAN scenario, can we still use STRIP option and setup the pvid in the kernel to make it work? That seems to be the only way I can merge this PR right now.

So the official libsai from some ASIC vendors don't have support for  attributes "SAI_HOSTIF_VLAN_TAG_STRIP and SAI_HOSTIF_VLAN_TAG_KEE" in sai_hostif_vlan_tag_t. 
While the two attributes or the better attribute SAI_HOSTIF_VLAN_TAG_ORIGINAL is mandatory for VLAN trunk support.  

We may put "return true;" at the beginning of bool PortsOrch::setHostIntfsStripTag(Port &port, sai_hostif_vlan_tag_t strip),  some the existing access vlan function won't be affected by the libsai issue.
We may just remove that line of code from the function once libsai support is ready which should happen really soon.

Please don't merge it until it's finished. Check all this fixmes in the source

~~~My understanding is that you use mutex to prevent multiple non-const operations on the same STL containers. Though, there is still chance that non-const operations will make const operation at risk, eg. invalidate an const iterator.~~~

Mutex is used to prevent any multiple access from different thread to AclOrch class data. We accessing AclOrch class from two threads. Main thread for write operations (create/delete tables, rules, counters) and counters thread to read counters. In both threads entry points are guarded with mutex. There is no chance that one thread will interrupt another in a middle of work. Can you please explain how it is possible to invalidate cont iterator and where?

latestReviews.body: I double checked. The mutex looks good to me.

comments.body: Fix for https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/issues/201 issue
@qiluo-msft , can you take a look at this?

>         for (auto table_it : pAclOrch->m_AclTables)

Accessing pAclOrch->m_AclTables is not thread safe.

---
Refers to: orchagent/aclorch.cpp:1319 in b4c84c8. [](commit_id = b4c84c85a06a5b807094befd6a88208b7c2a59b9, deletion_comment = False)

@qiluo-msft It is thread safe. Line you are referring is under m_countersMutex mutex:
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/blob/master/orchagent/aclorch.cpp#L1314

This line in "aclorch.cpp" will invalidate the iterator "table_it".
```
m_AclTables.erase(table_oid);
```


Another example: this line will invalidate the iterator "rule_it".
```
m_AclTables[table_oid].rules.erase(ruleIter);
```

I could not find the mechanism to prevent the risk conditions. In principle, C++11 standard guarantees that const method access to containers is safe from different threads (ie, both use const methods)
ref: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15067160/stdmap-thread-safety

My understanding there should be a readers-writer lock here for either container, or mutex for some performance trade-off.
@qiluo-msft fixed this in https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/pull/205 PR

comments.body:
This is to address the issue https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/issues/456.

The logic is already integrated in portsyncd which will update the oper_stauts of a port once the port changes its oper_status.

it is better to use orchagent to update the oper_status instead of using portsyncd
however, orchagent only gets oper_status of front panel ports notification from ASIC
vlan and port channel oper_status should still be updated from portsyncd

```
root@str-s6000-acs-11:/home/admin# ifdown Ethernet8
root@str-s6000-acs-11:/home/admin# redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall PORT_TABLE:Ethernet8
 1) "lanes"
 2) "37,38,39,40"
 3) "alias"
 4) "fortyGigE0/8"
 5) "admin_status"
 6) "down"
 7) "mtu"
 8) "1500"
 9) "oper_status"
10) "down"
root@str-s6000-acs-11:/home/admin# ifup Ethernet8
device Ethernet8 is already a member of a bridge; can't enslave it to bridge Vlan1000.
root@str-s6000-acs-11:/home/admin# redis-cli
127.0.0.1:6379> hgetall PORT_TABLE:Ethernet8
 1) "lanes"
 2) "37,38,39,40"
 3) "alias"
 4) "fortyGigE0/8"
 5) "admin_status"
 6) "up"
 7) "mtu"
 8) "1500"
 9) "oper_status"
10) "up"
```

commit message:
```
- Front panel ports' oper_status should be notified from the SAI instead of getting
  it from kernel via portsyncd. Thus in this commit, oper_status is removed from the
  portsyncd.

- VLAN and LAG oper_status on the contrary need to be updated from the protocol daemon,
  the kernel and the teamd.
```

comments.body: can you describe the nature of the issue a little bit more? what is the issue when accessing acl counters of inactive session? what is inactive session?

@lguohan Session with inactive state is session with unresolved route or next hop for its DST IP. It is not configured on hardware (so SAI OID is unavailable). To create ACL rule with action mirror we should have session in active state to be able to get its OID. If session is inactive ACL rules that depends on it can't be created on HW and have inactive state.
This fix prevents attempts to get ACL rule counters for rules in inactive state.
To address issue: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-swss/issues/160

comments.body: This pull request depends on https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/142
So the SAI implementation will only work when the action is set to forward before the next hop ID is updated?
Yes, this is limitation of MLNX SAI
